From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
CC: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2024-12-23 23:01
Subject: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Dee,
I hope this email finds you well.
I am sharing the Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich, secured through Marsh, for your review and feedback. Unfortunately, Nasco has not been able to secure concrete terms at this time, so I cannot recommend their proposal.
As such, Zurich’s proposal is the only viable proposal at this point, accepting the Chalhoub Risk profile on an as-is basis with no technical subjectivities.
Below, I have outlined the key details of the proposal for your consideration and feedback:
________________________________

Proposal Summary


Aspect
Details
Insurance Provider
Zurich (100%)
Annual Aggregate Limit
USD 5,000,000
Retention (Per Loss)
USD 500,000
Annual Premium
USD 350,000 (excl. fees & VAT)
Waiting Period
18 hours
Policy Wording
Marsh CyberWall / Zurich
Retroactive Date
Inception
Incident Response Vendor
Clyde & Co
________________________________

Aspect
Details
Insurance Provider
Zurich (100%)
Annual Aggregate Limit
USD 5,000,000
Retention (Per Loss)
USD 500,000
Annual Premium
USD 350,000 (excl. fees & VAT)
Waiting Period
18 hours
Policy Wording
Marsh CyberWall / Zurich
Retroactive Date
Inception
Incident Response Vendor
Clyde & Co
________________________________

Coverage Details
The maximum cover per incident is USD 5M, with subcategory limits as follows:
Coverage Type
Limit of Indemnity	 
Business Interruption	 USD 2.5M	 
Cyber Event Management Expenses	 USD 2.5M	 
Personal Data Protection	 USD 5M	 
Defense Costs and Investigation Penalties	 USD 5M	 
Payment Card Industry Penalties	 USD 5M	 
Cyber Extortion	 USD 2.5M	 
Breach of Confidentiality or Security Events	 USD 2.5M	 
Multimedia Cover	 USD 2.5M	 
Accidental Event (System Failure)	 USD 2.5M	 
Accidental Event at a Third Party (OSP)	 USD 2.5M

________________________________

Key Highlights and Considerations

*	
	Comprehensive Incident Response and Management

	*	The cyber insurance policy is not limited to covering costs; it provides an entire incident response and management service.
	*	This arrangement saves both time and money in the event of a cyber incident, particularly for low-frequency, high-urgency service needs.

*	
	Clyde & Co Management

	*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	
		Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	
		Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	
	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

	*	Chalhoub Group has the flexibility to nominate alternative service providers for any part of the event management process.
	*	This ensures cost-effectiveness or alignment with preferred suppliers.

________________________________

Future Opportunity with MFA Implementation
Upon achieving 100% Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) across all systems, we can improve the terms as follows with no increase in premium:    

*	Increase the aggregate limit to USD 10,000,000.
*	Reduce the retention to USD 250,000.
*	
	Remove subcategory indemnity limit caps.

This presents a strong incentive to prioritize full MFA implementation for enhanced coverage benefits.
________________________________

Pre-Binding Subjectivities


Requirement
Details
Confirmation of No Prior Incidents
No prior claims/incidents at time of binding
Consolidated Revenue
Approx. USD 2 billion
Exclusions
No subsidiaries/employees in Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine
________________________________

Risk Assessment by Marsh (Based on Industry (Retail) and Size (~USD 2bn TO)

The policy is well-positioned to cover average severity cyber events, and the pricing appears competitive for the size and scope of Chalhoub Group’s operations.
________________________________

Feedback Requested
I would appreciate your comments and whether this proposal is satisfactory from a technical perspective.
If you have no major concerns, we will proceed to push for a best and final offer to:

*	Increase some of the sub-limits.
*	Secure the best and final price.

Note that the cover is for all Chalhoub-managed companies. Turnover (TO) details provided does not include the TO of JVs. 
If any further details or clarification is required, please do advise. 
Thank You & Best Regards,
Hagop

I’m following up on the Zurich Cyber Insurance proposal I shared earlier and would appreciate your feedback. Once I have your input, I can move forward with requesting the final quotation and full policy wording from the broker. If there’s anything specific you’d like me to clarify or request from them, please let me know.

 

It would also be helpful to understand your targets for MFA implementation—at least for UAE and KSA, and ideally for Kuwait as well. This input will help us coordinate potential improvements to the policy, such as increasing the overall limit, improving the sublimits on reduced covers, and reducing the policy excess to around USD 250,000.

 

Let us aim to have the cover in place by the end of the month to establish a base level of insurance protection, and we can work on enhancing the policy limits and covers as our risk profile strengthens.

 

Thank you for your time and support. I look forward to your thoughts.

 

Best regards,

Hagop

--------------------------------------------------
Dear Dee,

Thank you for your email.

As requested, I’ve attached Zurich’s non-binding proposal for your review, along with the Marsh CyberWall policy wording, which is proprietary to Marsh.

While a legal review is important, your team’s insights on how well the coverage aligns with Chalhoub’s key risks would be invaluable at this stage. Also, I would greatly appreciate your particular feedback on the below:

*	Key Priorities: Please advise on any critical areas or enhancements we should prioritize.

*	Coverage Adjustments: Let me know if there are specific limits or risks that require further attention or adjustments.

If there are any constraints or particular improvements you’d like us to advocate for before requesting the final binding quotation, that would really be highly valuable.

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or need further clarification regarding the attached.

Dear Hagop, 

 

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.
	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.
	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.
	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.
	*	The requirement for prior written consent from the insurer for critical actions, such as hiring external vendors, incurring emergency costs, or initiating mitigation strategies, may delay the response to cyber incidents and increase financial and reputational risks.

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.
	*	No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

6.	Regulatory Compliance and Legal Assistance​​:

*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.
	*	No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

6.	Regulatory Compliance and Legal Assistance​​:

	*	Legal assistance sub-limits may not cover extensive cross-border disputes or large-scale regulatory investigations.
	*	Limited provisions for pre-emptive regulatory risk assessments or assistance with evolving international regulations.

7.	Reputation and Brand Damage​:

	*	Crisis communication and reputation recovery provisions have limited sub-limits, potentially leaving significant brand recovery efforts underfunded.

8.	Cybersecurity Standards and Controls​:

	*	Coverage may be conditional on adherence to minimum cybersecurity standards, but the policy does not clearly outline how non-compliance impacts claims.

9.	Emerging Threats and Technologies​​:

	*	No provisions for emerging cyber risks such as AI-driven attacks, deepfakes, or quantum computing vulnerabilities.

________________________________

Business Concerns

1.	Retention and Waiting Periods​:

chunks.text:
*	No provisions for emerging cyber risks such as AI-driven attacks, deepfakes, or quantum computing vulnerabilities.

________________________________

Business Concerns

1.	Retention and Waiting Periods​:

	*	Retention of $500,000 per incident and an 18-hour waiting period for business interruption claims may result in significant upfront costs for Chalhoub Group, especially for smaller incidents.

2.	Insufficient Limits for Ransomware Loss​:

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

	*	Limited focus on vendor or third-party risk management, which is critical given dependencies on supply chain IT systems.

4.	Geographic Exposures​:

	*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

________________________________

Recommendations for Proposal Changes

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

	*	Advocate for increased aggregate limits for ransomware and business interruption events to address severe loss scenarios.

2.	Expanded Mitigation and Incident Response Provisions:

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

	*	Advocate for increased aggregate limits for ransomware and business interruption events to address severe loss scenarios.

2.	Expanded Mitigation and Incident Response Provisions:

	*	Negotiate higher sub-limits for mitigation costs, incident response expenses, and loss preparation costs.

3.	Retention and Waiting Period Adjustments:

	*	Reduce retention or waiting periods to improve cost-effectiveness and responsiveness for small to mid-sized events.

4.	Inclusion of Betterment Clauses:

	*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

	*	Lower Automatic Inclusion Threshold: Adjust the threshold for automatic inclusion of subsidiaries from 25% to 50% of consolidated assets or revenue.
	*	Expand U.S. Market Coverage: Remove or adjust restrictions excluding entities with over 50% revenue from the U.S. market.
	*	Add Retroactive Coverage: Introduce retroactive coverage for inherited cybersecurity liabilities post-acquisition.
	*	Streamline Approval Process: Negotiate predefined criteria for insurer approval of larger acquisitions to avoid delays.
	*	Maintain Continuity Post-Merger: Include transitional coverage for six months following a change in control to ensure seamless integration and risk management.

7.	Provisions for Regulatory and Legal Risks:

Subject: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich

 

Dear Dee,

I hope this email finds you well.

I am sharing the Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich, secured through Marsh, for your review and feedback. Unfortunately, Nasco has not been able to secure concrete terms at this time, so I cannot recommend their proposal.

As such, Zurich’s proposal is the only viable proposal at this point, accepting the Chalhoub Risk profile on an as-is basis with no technical subjectivities.

Below, I have outlined the key details of the proposal for your consideration and feedback:

________________________________

Key Highlights and Considerations

*	Comprehensive Incident Response and Management

	*	The cyber insurance policy is not limited to covering costs; it provides an entire incident response and management service.
	*	This arrangement saves both time and money in the event of a cyber incident, particularly for low-frequency, high-urgency service needs.

*	Clyde & Co Management

	*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

	*	Chalhoub Group has the flexibility to nominate alternative service providers for any part of the event management process.
	*	This ensures cost-effectiveness or alignment with preferred suppliers.

________________________________

Future Opportunity with MFA Implementation

Upon achieving 100% Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) across all systems, we can improve the terms as follows with no increase in premium:    

*	Increase the aggregate limit to USD 10,000,000.
*	Reduce the retention to USD 250,000.
*	Remove subcategory indemnity limit caps.

This presents a strong incentive to prioritize full MFA implementation for enhanced coverage benefits.

Dear Hagop,

From: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com> 
Sent: 14 January 2025 12:40 PM
To: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>; Sara Rebeiz <Sara.Rebeiz@chalhoub.com>; Faraz Hasan <Faraz.hasan@chalhoub.com>
Cc: Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>; Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Sana Faiyaz <Sana.Faiyaz@chalhoub.com>
Subject: FW: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich

 

Dear Hagop, 

 

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.
	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.
	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.
	*	The requirement for prior written consent from the insurer for critical actions, such as hiring external vendors, incurring emergency costs, or initiating mitigation strategies, may delay the response to cyber incidents and increase financial and reputational risks.

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.
	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.
	*	The requirement for prior written consent from the insurer for critical actions, such as hiring external vendors, incurring emergency costs, or initiating mitigation strategies, may delay the response to cyber incidents and increase financial and reputational risks.

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.
	*	No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

6.	Regulatory Compliance and Legal Assistance​​:

	*	Legal assistance sub-limits may not cover extensive cross-border disputes or large-scale regulatory investigations.
	*	Limited provisions for pre-emptive regulatory risk assessments or assistance with evolving international regulations.

7.	Reputation and Brand Damage​:

	*	Crisis communication and reputation recovery provisions have limited sub-limits, potentially leaving significant brand recovery efforts underfunded.

8.	Cybersecurity Standards and Controls​:

chunks.text:
7.	Reputation and Brand Damage​:

	*	Crisis communication and reputation recovery provisions have limited sub-limits, potentially leaving significant brand recovery efforts underfunded.

8.	Cybersecurity Standards and Controls​:

	*	Coverage may be conditional on adherence to minimum cybersecurity standards, but the policy does not clearly outline how non-compliance impacts claims.

9.	Emerging Threats and Technologies​​:

	*	No provisions for emerging cyber risks such as AI-driven attacks, deepfakes, or quantum computing vulnerabilities.

________________________________

Business Concerns

1.	Retention and Waiting Periods​:

	*	Retention of $500,000 per incident and an 18-hour waiting period for business interruption claims may result in significant upfront costs for Chalhoub Group, especially for smaller incidents.

2.	Insufficient Limits for Ransomware Loss​:

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

	*	Limited focus on vendor or third-party risk management, which is critical given dependencies on supply chain IT systems.

4.	Geographic Exposures​:

	*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

________________________________

Recommendations for Proposal Changes

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

	*	Advocate for increased aggregate limits for ransomware and business interruption events to address severe loss scenarios.

2.	Expanded Mitigation and Incident Response Provisions:

	*	Negotiate higher sub-limits for mitigation costs, incident response expenses, and loss preparation costs.

3.	Retention and Waiting Period Adjustments:

	*	Reduce retention or waiting periods to improve cost-effectiveness and responsiveness for small to mid-sized events.

4.	Inclusion of Betterment Clauses:

	*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

	*	Lower Automatic Inclusion Threshold: Adjust the threshold for automatic inclusion of subsidiaries from 25% to 50% of consolidated assets or revenue.
	*	Expand U.S. Market Coverage: Remove or adjust restrictions excluding entities with over 50% revenue from the U.S. market.
	*	Add Retroactive Coverage: Introduce retroactive coverage for inherited cybersecurity liabilities post-acquisition.
	*	Streamline Approval Process: Negotiate predefined criteria for insurer approval of larger acquisitions to avoid delays.
	*	Maintain Continuity Post-Merger: Include transitional coverage for six months following a change in control to ensure seamless integration and risk management.

7.	Provisions for Regulatory and Legal Risks:

	*	Broaden coverage for pre-emptive compliance audits and cross-border legal disputes.

8.	Expanded Reputation Management:

	*	Seek higher sub-limits for reputation recovery efforts, including provisions for long-term rehabilitation campaigns.

9.	Prior Written Consent Causing Delays​​:

	*	Negotiate flexibility in obtaining insurer consent, including pre-approval of preferred vendors or retroactive approvals for urgent actions to ensure timely and effective incident response.

Kind Regards

Dee

Subject: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich

 

Dear Dee,

I hope this email finds you well.

I am sharing the Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich, secured through Marsh, for your review and feedback. Unfortunately, Nasco has not been able to secure concrete terms at this time, so I cannot recommend their proposal.

As such, Zurich’s proposal is the only viable proposal at this point, accepting the Chalhoub Risk profile on an as-is basis with no technical subjectivities.

Below, I have outlined the key details of the proposal for your consideration and feedback:

Key Highlights and Considerations

*	Comprehensive Incident Response and Management

	*	The cyber insurance policy is not limited to covering costs; it provides an entire incident response and management service.
	*	This arrangement saves both time and money in the event of a cyber incident, particularly for low-frequency, high-urgency service needs.

*	Clyde & Co Management

	*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

System Betterment: Betterment is generally excluded in cyber insurance, but it may be possible to negotiate a small sublimit (~USD 50k). However, any attack necessitating a replacement for hardware such as a compromised server for example, the replacement should be of a similar level of technological sophistication which would have been considered at the time of setup. (mid-level system at time of creation should be replaced by a mid-level system at time of replacements following an insured event. Anything above that would have to be paid out of pocket)

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

This exclusion is for willful or fraudulent act committed by key executives (CEO, CFO, COO, CRO), acting alone or in collusion. Note that the malicious damage in only limited to C-level executives, it does not exclude malicious damage caused by employees and the exclusion applies only if the act is proven through a final non-appealable adjudication or a written admission. Until then, it is business as usual.

 

 

External Infrastructure

*        Cloud or outsourced IT providers are covered up to USD 2.5M of the policy limit, but broader telecommunications or energy sector outages (outside of direct control) are excluded. However, the exclusion does not apply if the unavailability results in a Breach of confidentiality of personal data.

 

Example to illustrate the point:

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.

We can add coverage for this up to USD 50k. It is not an issue.

	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

We have a limit of USD 50,000 that we can exercise for emergency costs without requiring the approval of the insurer. This is reasonable.

Also we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

chunks.text:
Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Business Interruption (BI) coverage is limited to 6 months from the first financial impact. For Personal Data Protection, coverage extends up to 12 months from the date of discovery. We can try to increase the BI period to 12 months, but anything above that is unlikely.

Funding for pre-emptive advanced intelligence services or infrastructure enhancements is the responsibility of the insured, not the insurer. As for post the claim settlement, the insurer may fund any service they desire to recover the losses incurred by the insurer in relation post settlement of the claim amount. However, this is at the discretion of the insurer, not the insured. Once the claim is compensated according to the policy terms and conditions, the obligation of the insurer to the insured ends.

However, this is at the discretion of the insurer, not the insured. Once the claim is compensated according to the policy terms and conditions, the obligation of the insurer to the insured ends.

	*	The requirement for prior written consent from the insurer for critical actions, such as hiring external vendors, incurring emergency costs, or initiating mitigation strategies, may delay the response to cyber incidents and increase financial and reputational risks.

Requirements for prior written consent is generally limited to cyber extortion, major mitigation efforts, or public relations costs. In these cases, insurers commit to a 10-day response window. Furthermore, we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off in addition to the USD 50k provision available as emergency costs which we can exercise for time sensitive efforts outside of the scope of the insurer’s panel. 

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

chunks.text:
Requirements for prior written consent is generally limited to cyber extortion, major mitigation efforts, or public relations costs. In these cases, insurers commit to a 10-day response window. Furthermore, we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off in addition to the USD 50k provision available as emergency costs which we can exercise for time sensitive efforts outside of the scope of the insurer’s panel. 

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.

This is reasonable. If new entities acquired or merged with exceed 25% the parent company’s consolidated assets or revenue, insurers must review that entity’s risk before extending coverage. 25% of the parent company represents a merger or acquisition of a company with net assets or total revenue in excess of USD 500M. It would be a material change in the risk profile and the insurer has the right to study the risk.

 

No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

6.	Regulatory Compliance and Legal Assistance​​:

	*	Legal assistance sub-limits may not cover extensive cross-border disputes or large-scale regulatory investigations.

Business Concerns

1.	Retention and Waiting Periods​:

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

Agreed. Once the MFA fully implemented, we can very likely increase the limit of cover to USD 10M. However, based on the current risk profile, the proposal of Zurich limits the cover for Cyber extortion to USD 2.5M. I will push for a higher limit when requesting the best and final offer for Cyber extortion. The higher the limit provided, the better.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

	*	Limited focus on vendor or third-party risk management, which is critical given dependencies on supply chain IT systems.

Contingent Business Interruption for IT Providers is included (50% sublimit). Supply chain coverage for non-IT vendors also sits at 50%.

4.	Geographic Exposures​:

	*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

Sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus) are excluded due to regulatory requirements. Ukraine is excluded due to the high risk factor.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

Zurich generally allows vendors outside their preferred panel provided you obtain prior consent. If you intend to keep your Google Mandiant retainer, we will engage with Zurich to secure a written agreement to use Mandiant under the policy.

________________________________

Recommendations for Proposal Changes

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

	*	Advocate for increased aggregate limits for ransomware and business interruption events to address severe loss scenarios.

2.	Expanded Mitigation and Incident Response Provisions:

	*	Negotiate higher sub-limits for mitigation costs, incident response expenses, and loss preparation costs.

3.	Retention and Waiting Period Adjustments:

	*	Reduce retention or waiting periods to improve cost-effectiveness and responsiveness for small to mid-sized events.

4.	Inclusion of Betterment Clauses:

	*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

	*	Lower Automatic Inclusion Threshold: Adjust the threshold for automatic inclusion of subsidiaries from 25% to 50% of consolidated assets or revenue.
	*	Expand U.S. Market Coverage: Remove or adjust restrictions excluding entities with over 50% revenue from the U.S. market.
	*	Add Retroactive Coverage: Introduce retroactive coverage for inherited cybersecurity liabilities post-acquisition.
	*	Streamline Approval Process: Negotiate predefined criteria for insurer approval of larger acquisitions to avoid delays.
	*	Maintain Continuity Post-Merger: Include transitional coverage for six months following a change in control to ensure seamless integration and risk management.

7.	Provisions for Regulatory and Legal Risks:

	*	Broaden coverage for pre-emptive compliance audits and cross-border legal disputes.

8.	Expanded Reputation Management:

	*	Seek higher sub-limits for reputation recovery efforts, including provisions for long-term rehabilitation campaigns.

9.	Prior Written Consent Causing Delays​​:

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

System Betterment: Betterment is generally excluded in cyber insurance, but it may be possible to negotiate a small sublimit (~USD 50k). However, any attack necessitating a replacement for hardware such as a compromised server for example, the replacement should be of a similar level of technological sophistication which would have been considered at the time of setup. (mid-level system at time of creation should be replaced by a mid-level system at time of replacements following an insured event. Anything above that would have to be paid out of pocket)

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

metadata.doc_id: CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CWBMZVS - review and feedback on cyber insurance proposal from zurich\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

This exclusion is for willful or fraudulent act committed by key executives (CEO, CFO, COO, CRO), acting alone or in collusion. Note that the malicious damage in only limited to C-level executives, it does not exclude malicious damage caused by employees and the exclusion applies only if the act is proven through a final non-appealable adjudication or a written admission. Until then, it is business as usual.

 

 

External Infrastructure

*         Cloud or outsourced IT providers are covered up to USD 2.5M of the policy limit, but broader telecommunications or energy sector outages (outside of direct control) are excluded. However, the exclusion does not apply if the unavailability results in a Breach of confidentiality of personal data.

 

Example to illustrate the point:

*         Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*         Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

chunks.text:
*         Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*         Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.

We can add coverage for this up to USD 50k. It is not an issue.

	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

We have a limit of USD 50,000 that we can exercise for emergency costs without requiring the approval of the insurer. This is reasonable.

Also we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Business Interruption (BI) coverage is limited to 6 months from the first financial impact. For Personal Data Protection, coverage extends up to 12 months from the date of discovery. We can try to increase the BI period to 12 months, but anything above that is unlikely.

Funding for pre-emptive advanced intelligence services or infrastructure enhancements is the responsibility of the insured, not the insurer. As for post the claim settlement, the insurer may fund any service they desire to recover the losses incurred by the insurer in relation post settlement of the claim amount. However, this is at the discretion of the insurer, not the insured. Once the claim is compensated according to the policy terms and conditions, the obligation of the insurer to the insured ends.

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

Requirements for prior written consent is generally limited to cyber extortion, major mitigation efforts, or public relations costs. In these cases, insurers commit to a 10-day response window. 5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.

This is reasonable. If new entities acquired or merged with exceed 25% the parent company’s consolidated assets or revenue, insurers must review that entity’s risk before extending coverage. 25% of the parent company represents a merger or acquisition of a company with net assets or total revenue in excess of USD 500M. It would be a material change in the risk profile and the insurer has the right to study the risk.

 

No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

However, based on the current risk profile, the proposal of Zurich limits the cover for Cyber extortion to USD 2.5M. I will push for a higher limit when requesting the best and final offer for Cyber extortion. The higher the limit provided, the better.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

	*	Limited focus on vendor or third-party risk management, which is critical given dependencies on supply chain IT systems.

Contingent Business Interruption for IT Providers is included (50% sublimit). Supply chain coverage for non-IT vendors also sits at 50%.

4.	Geographic Exposures​:

	*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

Sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus) are excluded due to regulatory requirements. Ukraine is excluded due to the high risk factor.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

Subject: FW: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich

 

Dear Hagop, 

 

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

chunks.text:
*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

System Betterment: Betterment is generally excluded in cyber insurance, but it may be possible to negotiate a small sublimit (~USD 50k). However, any attack necessitating a replacement for hardware such as a compromised server for example, the replacement should be of a similar level of technological sophistication which would have been considered at the time of setup. (mid-level system at time of creation should be replaced by a mid-level system at time of replacements following an insured event. Anything above that would have to be paid out of pocket)

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

chunks.text:
System Betterment: Betterment is generally excluded in cyber insurance, but it may be possible to negotiate a small sublimit (~USD 50k). However, any attack necessitating a replacement for hardware such as a compromised server for example, the replacement should be of a similar level of technological sophistication which would have been considered at the time of setup. (mid-level system at time of creation should be replaced by a mid-level system at time of replacements following an insured event. Anything above that would have to be paid out of pocket)

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

This exclusion is for willful or fraudulent act committed by key executives (CEO, CFO, COO, CRO), acting alone or in collusion. Note that the malicious damage in only limited to C-level executives, it does not exclude malicious damage caused by employees and the exclusion applies only if the act is proven through a final non-appealable adjudication or a written admission. Until then, it is business as usual.

 

 

External Infrastructure

chunks.text:
This exclusion is for willful or fraudulent act committed by key executives (CEO, CFO, COO, CRO), acting alone or in collusion. Note that the malicious damage in only limited to C-level executives, it does not exclude malicious damage caused by employees and the exclusion applies only if the act is proven through a final non-appealable adjudication or a written admission. Until then, it is business as usual.

 

 

External Infrastructure

*        Cloud or outsourced IT providers are covered up to USD 2.5M of the policy limit, but broader telecommunications or energy sector outages (outside of direct control) are excluded. However, the exclusion does not apply if the unavailability results in a Breach of confidentiality of personal data.

 

Example to illustrate the point:

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.

We can add coverage for this up to USD 50k. It is not an issue.

	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

We have a limit of USD 50,000 that we can exercise for emergency costs without requiring the approval of the insurer. This is reasonable.

*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

We have a limit of USD 50,000 that we can exercise for emergency costs without requiring the approval of the insurer. This is reasonable.

Also we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Business Interruption (BI) coverage is limited to 6 months from the first financial impact. For Personal Data Protection, coverage extends up to 12 months from the date of discovery. We can try to increase the BI period to 12 months, but anything above that is unlikely.

Business Interruption (BI) coverage is limited to 6 months from the first financial impact. For Personal Data Protection, coverage extends up to 12 months from the date of discovery. We can try to increase the BI period to 12 months, but anything above that is unlikely.

Funding for pre-emptive advanced intelligence services or infrastructure enhancements is the responsibility of the insured, not the insurer. As for post the claim settlement, the insurer may fund any service they desire to recover the losses incurred by the insurer in relation post settlement of the claim amount. However, this is at the discretion of the insurer, not the insured. Once the claim is compensated according to the policy terms and conditions, the obligation of the insurer to the insured ends.

	*	The requirement for prior written consent from the insurer for critical actions, such as hiring external vendors, incurring emergency costs, or initiating mitigation strategies, may delay the response to cyber incidents and increase financial and reputational risks.

Requirements for prior written consent is generally limited to cyber extortion, major mitigation efforts, or public relations costs. In these cases, insurers commit to a 10-day response window. Furthermore, we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off in addition to the USD 50k provision available as emergency costs which we can exercise for time sensitive efforts outside of the scope of the insurer’s panel. 

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

chunks.text:
Requirements for prior written consent is generally limited to cyber extortion, major mitigation efforts, or public relations costs. In these cases, insurers commit to a 10-day response window. Furthermore, we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off in addition to the USD 50k provision available as emergency costs which we can exercise for time sensitive efforts outside of the scope of the insurer’s panel. 

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.

This is reasonable. If new entities acquired or merged with exceed 25% the parent company’s consolidated assets or revenue, insurers must review that entity’s risk before extending coverage. 25% of the parent company represents a merger or acquisition of a company with net assets or total revenue in excess of USD 500M. It would be a material change in the risk profile and the insurer has the right to study the risk.

 

No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

For acquired entities, coverage cannot stretch back for incidents that occurred before the acquisition date. We can try to push for a retroactive date but it would definitely exclude known incidents that have not be properly resolved.

6.	Regulatory Compliance and Legal Assistance​​:

	*	Legal assistance sub-limits may not cover extensive cross-border disputes or large-scale regulatory investigations.

Currently, legal expenses for cross-border or large-scale investigations are sublimited at 50% which is USD 2,500,000 out of the policy maximum aggregate limit of USD 5M which is reasonable.

	*	Limited provisions for pre-emptive regulatory risk assessments or assistance with evolving international regulations.

Pre-emptive risk assessment is the responsibility of the insured, not the insurer. The insurer is responsible for incident response only. If this is relating to professional fees post an incident, we can get it covered.

7.	Reputation and Brand Damage​:

I could not find any reference to this.

Business Concerns

1.	Retention and Waiting Periods​:

	*	Retention of $500,000 per incident and an 18-hour waiting period for business interruption claims may result in significant upfront costs for Chalhoub Group, especially for smaller incidents.

Once the risk profile is improved, we can negotiate for a reduction in the retention to USD 250k

2.	Insufficient Limits for Ransomware Loss​:

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

2.	Insufficient Limits for Ransomware Loss​:

	*	Ransomware is identified as the costliest potential cyber event, with high-severity cases potentially exceeding $40 million. The $5 million aggregate limit appears inadequate.

Agreed. Once the MFA fully implemented, we can very likely increase the limit of cover to USD 10M. However, based on the current risk profile, the proposal of Zurich limits the cover for Cyber extortion to USD 2.5M. I will push for a higher limit when requesting the best and final offer for Cyber extortion. The higher the limit provided, the better.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

	*	Limited focus on vendor or third-party risk management, which is critical given dependencies on supply chain IT systems.

Contingent Business Interruption for IT Providers is included (50% sublimit). Supply chain coverage for non-IT vendors also sits at 50%.

4.	Geographic Exposures​:

	*	Exclusion of subsidiaries or operations in sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus, Ukraine) may impact the ability to expand coverage for international risks or acquisitions.

Sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus) are excluded due to regulatory requirements. Ukraine is excluded due to the high risk factor.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

________________________________

Recommendations for Proposal Changes

1.	Higher Coverage Limits:

	*	Advocate for increased aggregate limits for ransomware and business interruption events to address severe loss scenarios.

2.	Expanded Mitigation and Incident Response Provisions:

	*	Negotiate higher sub-limits for mitigation costs, incident response expenses, and loss preparation costs.

3.	Retention and Waiting Period Adjustments:

	*	Reduce retention or waiting periods to improve cost-effectiveness and responsiveness for small to mid-sized events.

4.	Inclusion of Betterment Clauses:

	*	Request partial coverage for system betterment to future-proof IT systems and improve resilience.

5.	Enhanced Third-Party Risk and Supply Chain Provisions:

	*	Seek explicit coverage for third-party service disruptions and risks posed by external vendors.

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

6.	Revisions to Acquisition Provisions:

	*	Lower Automatic Inclusion Threshold: Adjust the threshold for automatic inclusion of subsidiaries from 25% to 50% of consolidated assets or revenue.
	*	Expand U.S. Market Coverage: Remove or adjust restrictions excluding entities with over 50% revenue from the U.S. market.
	*	Add Retroactive Coverage: Introduce retroactive coverage for inherited cybersecurity liabilities post-acquisition.
	*	Streamline Approval Process: Negotiate predefined criteria for insurer approval of larger acquisitions to avoid delays.
	*	Maintain Continuity Post-Merger: Include transitional coverage for six months following a change in control to ensure seamless integration and risk management.

7.	Provisions for Regulatory and Legal Risks:

	*	Broaden coverage for pre-emptive compliance audits and cross-border legal disputes.

8.	Expanded Reputation Management:

	*	Seek higher sub-limits for reputation recovery efforts, including provisions for long-term rehabilitation campaigns.

9.	Prior Written Consent Causing Delays​​:

	*	Negotiate flexibility in obtaining insurer consent, including pre-approval of preferred vendors or retroactive approvals for urgent actions to ensure timely and effective incident response.

Dear Dee,

I hope this email finds you well.

I am sharing the Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich, secured through Marsh, for your review and feedback. Unfortunately, Nasco has not been able to secure concrete terms at this time, so I cannot recommend their proposal.

As such, Zurich’s proposal is the only viable proposal at this point, accepting the Chalhoub Risk profile on an as-is basis with no technical subjectivities.

Below, I have outlined the key details of the proposal for your consideration and feedback:

________________________________

Key Highlights and Considerations

*	Comprehensive Incident Response and Management

	*	The cyber insurance policy is not limited to covering costs; it provides an entire incident response and management service.
	*	This arrangement saves both time and money in the event of a cyber incident, particularly for low-frequency, high-urgency service needs.

*	Clyde & Co Management

	*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

Upon achieving 100% Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) across all systems, we can improve the terms as follows with no increase in premium:

This presents a strong incentive to prioritize full MFA implementation for enhanced coverage benefits.

After reviewing both documents, I am looping in Legal to review the details alongside this summary and analysis. Below, I have outlined key issues, gaps, and potential areas for contestation from an information security business perspective:

Key Coverage Issues and Gaps

1.	Limitations on First Party Coverage (CyberWall)​:

	*	Indemnity limits on business interruption, expenses, and cyber extortion are capped at 50% of the policy limit, potentially leaving significant residual risk uncovered.
	*	No coverage for system betterment or enhancements post-breach unless the original components are unavailable.

Indemnity Limits: This proposal was provided accepting the Chalhoub profile on an as-is basis. As such, certain limitations in cover are expected. As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

As advised in the e-mail trail, once full MFA is in place, we can increase the coverage limit for all categories up to USD 10M at no change in premium. That beings said, the aggregate limit is still USD 5,000,000. As such, even though some specific categories are capped, the losses relating to the different categories are additive

System Betterment: Betterment is generally excluded in cyber insurance, but it may be possible to negotiate a small sublimit (~USD 50k). However, any attack necessitating a replacement for hardware such as a compromised server for example, the replacement should be of a similar level of technological sophistication which would have been considered at the time of setup. (mid-level system at time of creation should be replaced by a mid-level system at time of replacements following an insured event. Anything above that would have to be paid out of pocket)

2.	Exclusions That Limit Coverage Scope​:

	*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

chunks.text:
*	Intentional Acts: Excludes events caused by wilful misconduct of high-level executives, which could create challenges in disputes over accountability.
	*	External Infrastructure: No coverage for unavailability of third-party infrastructure like cloud providers unless related to data breaches, which is a critical dependency in modern IT ecosystems.

Intentional Acts (Willful Misconduct)

 

A wilful act is standard exclusion under any policy.

This exclusion is for willful or fraudulent act committed by key executives (CEO, CFO, COO, CRO), acting alone or in collusion. Note that the malicious damage in only limited to C-level executives, it does not exclude malicious damage caused by employees and the exclusion applies only if the act is proven through a final non-appealable adjudication or a written admission. Until then, it is business as usual.

 

 

External Infrastructure

*        Cloud or outsourced IT providers are covered up to USD 2.5M of the policy limit, but broader telecommunications or energy sector outages (outside of direct control) are excluded. However, the exclusion does not apply if the unavailability results in a Breach of confidentiality of personal data.

 

Example to illustrate the point:

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

chunks.text:
*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in financial loss. - Not covered

*       Power outage causes downtime for our IT systems, resulting in breach of personal data confidentiality –Covered

3.	Incident Response and Loss Recovery Gaps​:

	*	Loss preparation costs are excluded, which limits the ability to recover expenses for forensic investigations and claim preparation.

We can add coverage for this up to USD 50k. It is not an issue.

	*	Emergency cost sub-limits ($50,000) might be inadequate for responding to large-scale or complex incidents.

We have a limit of USD 50,000 that we can exercise for emergency costs without requiring the approval of the insurer. This is reasonable.

Also we would have access to a 24/7 hotline from the insurer’s panel, allowing immediate reaction without prior sign-off.

4.	Mitigation and Proactive Risk Management​​:

	*	Mitigation costs are limited to 10% of the indemnity limit, restricting proactive measures post-incident.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Mitigation costs are included up to USD 500,000 (10% of indemnity limit). This mean that in case of an incident, if there are any actions that we can take to reduce the loss, the policy will generally cover up to USD 500,000. However, it is important to note that the mitigating action should provide an anticipated reduction in the quantifiable loss of the incident for a sum that is equal or higher than what the loss would be otherwise if no mitigating action is taken.

	*	Lack of provisions for funding long-term recovery or advanced threat intelligence services.

Business Interruption (BI) coverage is limited to 6 months from the first financial impact. For Personal Data Protection, coverage extends up to 12 months from the date of discovery. We can try to increase the BI period to 12 months, but anything above that is unlikely.

Funding for pre-emptive advanced intelligence services or infrastructure enhancements is the responsibility of the insured, not the insurer. As for post the claim settlement, the insurer may fund any service they desire to recover the losses incurred by the insurer in relation post settlement of the claim amount. However, this is at the discretion of the insurer, not the insured. Once the claim is compensated according to the policy terms and conditions, the obligation of the insurer to the insured ends.

5.	Acquisition-Related Coverage Gaps​:

	*	Automatic Inclusion: Automatic coverage is limited to subsidiaries with less than 25% of consolidated assets or revenue and excludes entities with over 50% of revenue from the U.S. market. This threshold may leave significant acquisitions uncovered.
	*	Approval Delays: Larger acquisitions require insurer approval, risking delays, and potential coverage gaps during critical early stages of integration.

This is reasonable. If new entities acquired or merged with exceed 25% the parent company’s consolidated assets or revenue, insurers must review that entity’s risk before extending coverage. 25% of the parent company represents a merger or acquisition of a company with net assets or total revenue in excess of USD 500M. It would be a material change in the risk profile and the insurer has the right to study the risk.

 

No Retroactive Coverage: Coverage applies only to events occurring after the acquisition, leaving inherited cybersecurity liabilities unaddressed.

3.	Unaddressed Supply Chain Risks​​:

Sanctioned regions (Russia, Belarus) are excluded due to regulatory requirements. Ukraine is excluded due to the high risk factor.

5.	Incident Response Timeline and Vendor Restrictions​:

	*	Mandatory use of specific vendors for incident response and legal services limits flexibility,  we cannot adhere to this we have an Incident Response retainer with Google Mandiant.

Subject: Review and Feedback on Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich

I hope this email finds you well.

I am sharing the Cyber Insurance Proposal from Zurich, secured through Marsh, for your review and feedback. Unfortunately, Nasco has not been able to secure concrete terms at this time, so I cannot recommend their proposal.

As such, Zurich’s proposal is the only viable proposal at this point, accepting the Chalhoub Risk profile on an as-is basis with no technical subjectivities.

Below, I have outlined the key details of the proposal for your consideration and feedback:

Coverage Details

The maximum cover per incident is USD 5M, with subcategory limits as follows:

________________________________

Key Highlights and Considerations

*	Comprehensive Incident Response and Management

	*	The cyber insurance policy is not limited to covering costs; it provides an entire incident response and management service.
	*	This arrangement saves both time and money in the event of a cyber incident, particularly for low-frequency, high-urgency service needs.

*	Clyde & Co Management

	*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

*	Zurich would appoint Clyde & Co for incident management, with pre-negotiated rates leveraged by Zurich’s economies of scale.
	*	Clyde & Co offers access to industry-leading experts across professional, technical, legal, media, and other areas to ensure effective post-incident management.

*	Flexibility in Vendor Selection

	*	Chalhoub Group has the flexibility to nominate alternative service providers for any part of the event management process.
	*	This ensures cost-effectiveness or alignment with preferred suppliers.

________________________________

Future Opportunity with MFA Implementation

Upon achieving 100% Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) across all systems, we can improve the terms as follows with no increase in premium:    

*	Increase the aggregate limit to USD 10,000,000.
*	Reduce the retention to USD 250,000.
*	Remove subcategory indemnity limit caps.

This presents a strong incentive to prioritize full MFA implementation for enhanced coverage benefits.

________________________________

Consolidated Revenue

No subsidiaries/employees in Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine

________________________________
